ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: this class helped me learn not only Chinese language but also the cultural and historical context
Learned to analyze contemporary media in Chinese. Learned more advanced Chinese vocab than what is necessary for basic conversations.
Increasing in Chinese speaking fluency, reading comprehension, cultural knowledge

We read several texts from Chinese writers (Lu Xun, Mo Yan) and watched several well-known Chinese films (Zhang Yimou, Li An, Chen Kaige). A lot of the vocabulary was about social/political topics, but there were also a fair few lessons that included more "everyday" vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
No weakness.

Great teacher with great course content

Strengths: Shen laoshi is awesome and so nice. You get to do your essays/presentations on topics of your choosing.
Cons: not a lot of class discussion/participation.

Strengths: The readings and the movies we watch are interesting. Sometimes we discuss stuff like politics and cultural differences in class and that's always interesting.

Weaknesses: If you don't come prepared, having done the reading, you probably won't get as much out of the class.

The strengths of this course are much like most of Yale's Chinese courses -- just the right amount of vocabulary, interesting topics, an encouraging teacher in Shen Laoshi, and, at this level, not too high of a workload. My one suggestion for improvement might actually be to increase the amount of homework slightly: with only one comprehension quiz and one essay per lesson, there wasn't a lot of incentive to really internalize the vocabulary/grammar or practice it outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would.

You can learn so many different aspect of China, in addition to the language.

Yes! Taking Chinese at Yale is usually a lot of work but this class was less intense than previous L1-L5 classes, and generally more fun. The topics discussed in class are interesting, plus the workload is less than I was expecting (no weekly tingxies, exams were pretty easy). If you're on the fence about taking Chinese because you're intimidated by the workload, this class is a good way to stay sharp with your Chinese without having to dedicate too much time to the class.
